Dialogue: That's all right, Mr. Bernstein.

Dialogue: Leland and Mr. Kane - they haven't spoke together for ten years.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Hey, Brad!  Brad!  He ain't been drinking before, Mr. Kane.  Never.  We would have heard.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What does it say there?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What's he written?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I can't pronounce that name, Mr. Kane.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Thais.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Go on!

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: That's all there is.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Of her acting, it is absolutely impossible to say anything except that it represents a new low...  Have you got that, Mr. Bernstein? In the opinion of this reviewer -

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I didn't see that.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It isn't here, Mr. Bernstein.  I'm dictating it.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I can't take shorthand.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Get me a typewriter.  I'll finish the notice.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: He finished it.  He wrote the worst notice I ever read about the girl he loved.  We ran it in every paper.

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: I guess Mr. Kane didn't think so well of Susie's art anyway.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: He thought she was great, Mr. Thompson.  He really believed that. He put all his ambition on that girl.  After she came along, he never really cared for himself like he used to.  Oh, I don't blame Susie -

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Well, then, how could he write that roast?  The notices in the Kane papers were always very kind to her.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Oh, yes.  He saw to that.  I tell you, Mr. Thompson, he was a hard man to figure out.  He had that funny sense of humor.  And then, too, maybe he thought by finishing that piece he could show Leland he was an honest man.  You see, Leland didn't think so.  I guess he showed him all right.  He's a nice fellow, but he's a dreamer.  They were always together in those early days when we just started the Enquirer.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: Welcome, Mr. Kane, to the "Enquirer."  I am Herbert Carter.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Thank you, Mr Carter.  This is Mr. Leland.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: How do you do, Mr. Leland?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Are they standing for me?

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: I thought it would be a nice gesture the new publisher -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Ask them to sit down.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: You may resume your work, gentlemen.  I didn't know your plans and so I was unable to make any preparations.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I don't my plans myself.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: As a matter of fact, I haven't got any.  Except to get out a newspaper.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Bernstein!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: If you would come here a moment, please, Mr. Bernstein?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Mr. Carter, this is Mr. Bernstein. Mr. Bernstein is my general manager.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: How do you do, Mr. Bernstein?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You've got a private office here, haven't you?

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: My little sanctum is at your disposal.  But I don't think I understand -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'm going to live right here.  As long as I have to.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: But a morning newspaper, Mr. Kane. After all, we're practically closed twelve hours a day - except for the business offices -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: That's one of the things I think must be changed, Mr. Carter.  The news goes on for twenty-four hours a day.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'm not criticizing, Mr. Carter, but here's what I mean.  There's a front page story in the "Chronicle,"  A Mrs. Harry Silverstone.  Why didn't the "Enquirer" have that this morning?

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: Because we're running a newspaper, Mr.  Kane, not a scandal sheet.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'm still hungry, Brad.  Let's go to Rector's and get something decent.  The "Chronicle" has a two-column headline, Mr. Carter.  Why haven't we?

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: There is no news big enough.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: If the headline is big enough, it makes the new big enough.  The murder of Mrs. Harry Silverstone -

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: Our man even arrived before the "Chronicle" reporter.  And there's no proof that the woman was murdered - or even that she's dead.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: The "Chronicle" doesn't say she's murdered, Mr. Carter.  It says the neighbors are getting suspicious.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: It's not our function to report the gossip of housewives.  If we were interested in that kind of thing, Mr. Kane, we could fill the paper twice over daily -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Have him tell Mr. Silverstone he's a detective from the Central Office. If Mr. Silverstone asks to see his badge, your man is to get indignant and call Mr. Silverstone an anarchist.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: Really, Mr. Kane, I can't see the function of a respectable newspaper -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Bernstein!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I've just made a shocking discovery. The "Enquirer" is without a telephone.  Have two installed at once!

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I ordered six already this morning! Got a discount!

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: But, Mr. Kane -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: That'll be all today, Mr. Carter. You've been most understanding. Good day, Mr. Carter!

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Poor Mr. Carter!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What makes those fellows think that a newspaper is something rigid, something inflexible, that people are supposed to pay two cents for -

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Three cents.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Two cents.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: This is all figured at three cents a copy.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Re-figure it, Mr. Bernstein, at two cents.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: All right, but I'll keep these figures, too, just in case.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Ready for dinner, Brad?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Mr. Leland, if Mr. Kane, he should decide to drop the price to one cent, or maybe even he should make up his mind to give the paper away with a half-pound of tea - you'll just hold him until I get back, won't you?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I'm not guaranteeing a thing, Mr. Bernstein.  You people work too fast for me!  Talk about new brooms!

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Who said anything about brooms?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It's a saying, Mr. Bernstein.  A new broom sweeps clean.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: smathers
Dialogue: But it's impossible, Mr. Kane.  We can't remake these pages.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: These pages aren't made up as I want them, Mr. Smathers.  We go to press in five minutes.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: The "Enquirer" has an old and honored tradition, Mr. Kane... The "Enquirer" is not in competition with those other rags.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: We should be publishing such rags, that's all I wish.  Why, the "Enquirer" - I wouldn't wrap up the liver for the cat in the "Enquirer" -

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: Mr. Kane, I must ask you to see to it that this - this person learns to control his tongue.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: I've been a newspaperman my whole life and I don't intend -  I warn you, Mr. Kane, it would go against my grain to desert you when you need me so badly - but I would feel obliged to ask that my resignation be accepted.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It is accepted, Mr. Carter, with assurances of my deepest regard.

Speaker: carter
Dialogue: But Mr. Kane, I meant -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Let's remake these pages, Mr. Smathers.  We'll have to publish a half hour late, that's all.

Speaker: smathers
Dialogue: We can't remake them, Mr. Kane. We go to press in five minutes.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You can remake them now, can't you, Mr. Smathers?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: After the types 've been reset and the pages have been remade according to the way I told you before, Mr. Smathers, kindly have proofs pulled and bring them to me.  Then, if I can't find any way to improve them again -  - I suppose we'll have to go to press.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: In case you don't understand, Mr. Smathers - he's a new broom.

Speaker: newsboys' voices
Dialogue: CHRONICLE!  CHRONICLE!  H'YA - THE CHRONICLE - GET YA!  CHRONICLE!

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: We'll be on the street soon, Charlie - another ten minutes.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: It's three hours and fifty minutes late - but we did it -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Tired?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: It's been a tough day.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: A wasted day.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Wasted?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Charlie?!

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: You just made the paper over four times today, Mr. Kane.  That's all -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I've changed the front page a little, Mr. Bernstein.  That's not enough - There's something I've got to get into this paper besides pictures and print -  I've got to make the "New York Enquirer" as important to New York as the gas in that light.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: What're you going to do, Charlie?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: My Declaration of Principles -  Take dictation, Mr. Bernstein -

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Can't take shorthand, Mr. Kane -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'll write it myself.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: You don't wanta make any promises, Mr. Kane, you don't wanta keep.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: will also provide them -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: That's the second sentence you've started with "I" -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: And no special interests will be allowed to interfere with the truth of that news.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Sixty-two thousand -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: That looks pretty nice.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Let's hope they like it there.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: From the Chronicle Building that sign is the biggest thing you can see - every floor guaranteed - let's hope it bothers them - it cost us enough.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Look at that.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: The "Chronicle" is a good newspaper.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It's a good idea for a newspaper.  Four hundred sixy thousand.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Say, with them fellows -  - it's no trick to get circulation.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You're right, Mr. Bernstein.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: You know how long it took the "Chronicle" to get that staff together?  Twenty years.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: photographer
Dialogue: That's all.  Thank you.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Make up an extra copy and mail it to the "Chronicle."

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Gentlemen of the "Enquirer"!  This has, I think, been a fitting welcome to those distinguished journalists -  Mr. Reilly in particular - who are the latest additions to our ranks. It will make them happy to learn that the "Enquirer's" circulation this morning passed the two hundred thousand mark.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Two hundred and one thousand, six hundred and forty-seven.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: All of you - new and old -  You're all getting the best salaries in town.  Not one of you has been hired because of his loyalty. It's your talent I'm interested in.  That talent that's going to make the "Enquirer" the kind of paper I want - the best newspaper in the world!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: However, I think you'll agree we've heard enough about newspapers and the newspaper business for one night.  There are other subjects in the world.

Speaker: the official
Dialogue: There you are, Mr. Kane.  Everything in order.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: the official
Dialogue: Have a good rest, Mr. Kane.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: But please, Mr. Kane, don't buy any more paintings.  Nine Venuses already we got, twenty-six Virgins - two whole warehouses full of stuff -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I promise not to bring any more Venuses and not to worry - and not to try to get in touch with any of the papers -

Speaker: steward's voice
Dialogue: All ashore!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: - and to forget about the new feature sections - and not to try to think up and ideas for comic sections.

Speaker: steward's voice
Dialogue: All ashore that's going ashore!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Goodbye, gents!  Hey!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You don't expect me to keep any of those promises, do you?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Do you, Mr. Leland?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Ask them to sit down, Mr. Bernstein.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Sit down, everybody - for heaven's sake!

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: So then, tonight, we go over everything thoroughly, eh? Especially the new papers -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: We certainly do.  Vacation's over - starting right after dinner.  But right now - that lady over there -  - that's the new society editor, I take it?  You think I could interrupt her a moment, Mr. Bernstein?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Huh?  Oh, I forgot - you've been away so long I forgot about your joking -

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Miss Townsend -

Speaker: miss townsend
Dialogue: Good afternoon, Mr. Bernstein.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: This is Mr. Kane, Miss Townsend.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Miss Townsend -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I've been away for several months, and I don't know exactly how these things are handled now.  But one thing I wanted to be sure of is that you won't treat this little announcement any differently than you would any other similar announcement.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Read it, Miss Townsend.  And remember - just the regular treatment!  See you at nine o'clock, Mr. Bernstein!

Speaker: miss townsend
Dialogue: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Moore Norton announce the engagement of their daughter, Emily Monroe Norton, to Mr.  Charles Foster Kane.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Moore Norton announce -

Speaker: miss townsend
Dialogue: She's - she's the niece of - of the President of the United States -

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: know.  Come on, Miss Townsend - From the window, maybe we can get a look.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: A girl like that, believe me, she's lucky!  Presiden't niece, huh! Say, before he's through, she'll be a Presiden't wife.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: The way things turned out, I don't need to tell you - Miss Emily Norton was no rosebud!

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: It didn't end very well, did it?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: guess he didn't make her very happy -

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Yes -

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Maybe that was something he lost. Mr. Kane was a man that lost - almost everything he had -  You ought to talk to Bradford Leland.  He could tell you a lot. I wish I could tell you where Leland is, but I don't know myself.  He may be out of town somewhere - he may be dead.

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: In case you'd like to know, Mr. Bernstein, he's at the Huntington Memorial Hospital on 180th Street.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: You don't say!  Why I had no idea -

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Nothing particular the matter with him, they tell me.  Just -

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Just old age.  You ought to see Mr. Leland. There's a whole lot of things he could tell you - if he wanted to.

Speaker: leland's voice
Dialogue: When you get to my age, young man, you don't miss anything.  Unless maybe it's a good drink of bourbon. Even that doesn't make much difference, if you remember there hasn't been any good bourbon in this country for twenty years.

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Mr. Leland, you were -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: You don't happen to have a cigar, do you?  I've got a young physician - must remember to ask to see his license - the odds are a hundred to one he hasn't got one - who thinks I'm going to stop smoking... I changed the subject, didn't I? Dear, dear!  What a disagreeable old man I've become.  You want to know what I think of Charlie Kane? Well - I suppose he has some private sort of greatness.  But he kept it to himself.  You're absolutely sure you haven't got a cigar?

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Sorry, Mr. Leland.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Never mind -  Bernstein told you about the first days at the office, didn't he?  Well, Charlie was a bad newspaper man even then.  He entertained his readers, but he never told them the truth.

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Maybe you could remember something that -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I can remember everything.  That's my curse, young man.  It's the greatest curse that's ever been inflicted on the human race.  Memory - I was his oldest friend.  As far as I was concerned, he behaved like swine.  Maybe I wasnt' his friend.  If I wasn't, he never had one.  Maybe I was what nowadays you call a stooge -

Speaker: kane's voice
Dialogue: Not one of you has been hired because of his loyalty.  It's your talent I'm interested in.  That talent that's going to make the "Enquirer" the kind of paper I want - the best newspaper in the world!

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Isn't it wonderful?  Such a party!

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: kane's voice
Dialogue: However, I think you'll agree we've heard enough about newspapers and the newspaper business for one night.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Mr. Bernstein, these men who are now with the "Enquirer" - who were with the "Chronicle" until yesterday - weren't they just as devoted to the "Chronicle" kind of paper as they are now to - our kind of paper?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Sure.  They're like anybody else. They got work to do.  They do it.  Only they happen to be the best men in the business.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: There are other subjects in the world -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Do we stand for the same things that the "Chronicle" stands for, Mr. Bernstein?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Certainly not.  So what's that got to do with it?  Mr. Kane, he'll have them changed to his kind of newspapermen in a week.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Probably.  There's always a chance, of course, that they'll change Mr. Kane - without his knowing it.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Well, gentlemen, are we going to war?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Our readers are, anyway, I don't know about the rest of the country.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: By Bradford Leland, the "Enquirer's" Special Correspondent at the Front. I'm almost tempted -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: But there is no Front, Charlie. There's a very doubtful civil war. Besides, I don't want the job.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: All right, Brad, all right - you don't have to be a war correspondent unless you want to - I'd want to.  Hello, Georgie.

Speaker: georgie
Dialogue: Is everything the way you want it, dear?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: If everybody's having fun, that's the way I want it.

Speaker: georgie
Dialogue: I've got some other little girls coming over -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Charles, I tell you there is no war!  There's a condition that should be remedied - but between that and a -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: How would the "Enquirer" look with no news about this non-existent war - with Benton, Pulitzer and Heart devoting twenty columns a day to it?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: They do it only because you do!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'm going over to Georgie's, Brad - you know, Georgie, don't you?

Speaker: georgie
Dialogue: Glad to meet you, Brad.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I told you about Brad, Georgie. He needs to relax.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Some ships with wonderful wines have managed to slip through the enemy fleet that's blockading New York harbor -  What's her name again?

Speaker: georgie
Dialogue: Ethel - this gentlemen has been very anxious to meet you -  This is Ethel.

Speaker: ethel
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Leland.

Speaker: another girl
Dialogue: Is there a song about Charlie?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Say, Brad.  I've got an idea.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I mean I've got a job for you.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You don't want to be a war correspondent - how about being a dramatic critic?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I'd like that.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You start tomorrow night.  Richard Carl in "The Spring Chicken."  Rector's at seven?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Charlie -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: It doesn't make any difference about me, but one of these days you're going to find out that all this charm of yours won't be enough -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Come to think of it, I don't blame you for not wanting to be a war correspondent.  You won't miss anything.  It isn't much of a war. Besides, they tell me there isn't a decent restaurant on the whole island.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You don't expect me to keep any of those promises, do you?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Do you, Mr. Leland?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Mr. Leland, why didn't you go to Europe with him?  He wanted you to.  He said to me just yesterday -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I wanted him to have fun - and with me along -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Mr. Bernstein, I wish you'd let me ask you a few questions, and answer me truthfully.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Don't I always?  Most of the time?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Mr. Bernstein, am I a stuffed shirt? Am I a horse-faced hypocrite?  Am I a New England school-marm?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: If you thought I'd answer different from what Mr. Kane tells you - well, I wouldn't.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: You're in a conspiracy against me, you two.  You always have been.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Against me there should be such a conspiracy some time!

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Well, he'll be coming back in September.  The Majestic.  I got the reservations.  It gets in on the ninth.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: September the ninth?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I used to go to dancing school with her.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: It's a letter from her lawyers.

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Rawlston is my boss.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Oh, yes.  I know about Mr. Rawlston.

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: He knows the first Mrs. Kane socially -  That's the answer we got.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I am in receipt of your favor of yesterday.  I beg you to do me the courtesy of accepting my assurance that Mrs. Whitehall cannot be induced to contribute any more information on the career of Charles Foster Kane.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Brief marriage!  Ten years!

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Was he in love?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: He married for love -  That's why he did everything. That's why he went into politics. It seems we weren't enough.  He wanted all the voters to love him, too.  All he really wanted out of life was love.  That's Charlie's story - it's the story of how he lost it.  You see, he just didn't have any to give.  He loved Charlie Kane, of course, very dearly - and his mother, I guess he always loved her.  As for Emily - well, all I can tell you is Emily's story as she told it to me, which probably isn't fair - there's supposed to be two sides to every story - and I guess there are.  I guess there's more than two sides -

Speaker: the president
Dialogue: It is the unanimous opinion of my Cabinent - in which I concur - that the proposed leases are in the best interests of the Governement and the people.  You are not, I hope, suggesting that these interests are not indentical?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'm not suggesting anything, Mr. President!  I've come here to tell you that, unless some action is taken promptly - and you are the only one who can take it - the oil that is the property of the people of this country will be turned over for a song to a gang of high- pressure crooks!

Speaker: the president
Dialogue: I must refuse to allow you to continue in this vein, Mr. Kane.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It's the only vein I know.  I tell the facts the way I see them.  And any man that knows that facts -

Speaker: the president
Dialogue: I know the facts, Mr. Kane.  And I happen to have the incredible insolence to differ with you as to what they mean.  You're a man of great talents, Mr. Kane.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: the president
Dialogue: I understand that you have political ambitions.  Unfortunately, you seem incapable of allowing any other opinion but your own -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'm much obliged, Mr. President, for your concern about me.  However, I happen to be concerned at this moment with the matter of extensive oil lands belonging to the people of the United States, and I say that if this lease goes through, the property of the people of the United States goes into the hands of -

Speaker: the president
Dialogue: You've made your point perfectly clear, Mr. Kane.  Good day.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Mr. President.

Speaker: foreman
Dialogue: How about it, Mr. Kane?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: All right.  Let her slide!

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Looks bad for us, Mr. Kane.  How shall we handle it?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It's a news story!  Get it on the street!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Take dictation -  Front page editorial -  "This afternoon a great man was assassinated.  He was the President of the United States -"

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Charlie -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Do you think you're the one who should call him a great man?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Why not?  Well - nobody's a great man in your estimation until he's dead.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Maybe we'd better wait for more word on the President's condition.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What do you mean by that?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Competition.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: He may recover -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What do you mean by that?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Yesterday morning you called the President a traitor.  What do you think that crowd is doing down there?  They think you murdered him.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Because the crackpot who did it had a copy of the "Enquirer" in his pocket?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: - and that copy of the "Enquirer" said the President should be killed.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I said treason was a capital offense punishable by death -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: You've said a lot of things about the President in the last few months.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: They're true!  Everything I said! Witholding that veto was treason!

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Charlie!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Oil belonging to the people of the United States was leased out for a song to a gang of high-pressure crooks -  Nobody can blame me because -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Look out that window.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: There are the people of the United States, and they are blaming you - Oh, I know it doesn't make any sense, but at least you can learn a lesson from it.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Run it the way I said, Reilly - "This afternoon a great man was assassinated -"

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Charlie!  Now you're not making sense.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I don't have to.  I run a newspaper with half a million readers and they're getting a martyred president this morning with their breakfast. I can't help that.  Besides, they all know I'm married to his niece. I've got to think of her.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I've got to think of Emily -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I'd like to talk to you about that.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Go ahead.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Finish your editorial.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: What's happened?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I'm all right, Mr. Leland.  Only there was some fellows out front that thought they ought to take things up with me.  I learned 'em! Didn't I, officer?

Speaker: the cop
Dialogue: You sure did -  Say, the Commissioner said I was to stand by and protect Mr. Kane until further orders, no matter how he felt about it.  Where is he?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: In there.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: If you hadn't come along and protected me when you did, I'd have killed them fellows.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: There doesn't seem to be an serious injury.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Not to me.  But you will let that cop go home with Mr. Kane, won't you?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Bernstein.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Goodnight, Mr. Kane.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: First of all -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What's wrong, Brad?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I'm drunk.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'll get you some coffee.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: First of all, I will not write a good review of a play because somebody paid a thousand dollars for an advertisement in the "Enquirer."

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Mike, will you try and get Mr. Leland some coffee?

Speaker: mike's voice
Dialogue: Sure thing, Mr. Kane.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Charlie, it's just no go.  We can't agree anymore.  I wish you'd let me go to Chicago.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Why, Brad?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I want to be transferred to the new paper.  You've been saying yourself you wish you had somebody to -  That's not what I wanted to talk about.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'll tell you what I'll do, Brad - I'll get drunk, too - maybe that'll help.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: No, that won't help.  Besides, you never get drunk.  I wanted to talk about you and Emily.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: She's going to leave you -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I don't think so, Brad.  We've just had word that the President is out of danger.  It seems I didn't kill him after all.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: She was going to leave you anyway -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Emily's going south next week with the child.  As far as anybody's to know, it's a holiday.  When they get back -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Brad, you are drunk.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Sure I am.  She wants full custody of the child no matter what happens. If you won't agree to that, she'll apply for a divorce regardless of the President's wishes.  I can't tell her she's wrong, because she isn't wrong -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Why is she leaving me?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: She hasn't any friends left sine you started this oil business, and she never sees you.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Do you think the "Enquirer" shouldn't have campaigned against the oil leases?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: You might have made the whole thing less personal!

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: It isn't just that the President was her uncle - everyone she knows, all the people she's been brought up with, everything she's ever been taught to believe is important -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: There's no reason why this - this savage personal note -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: The personal note is all there is to it.  It's all there ever is to it.  It's all there every is to anything!  Stupidity in our government, complacency and self- satisfaction and unwillingness to believe that anything done by a certain class of people can be wrong - you can't fight those things impersonally.  They're not impersonal crimes against people. They're being done by actual persons - with actual names and positions and - the right of the American people to own their own country is not an academic issue, Brad, that you debate - and then the judges retire to return a verdict and the winners give a dinner for the losers.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: You almost convince me.  You only associate with your inferiors, Charlie.  I guess that's why you ran away from Emily. Because you can't stand the company of your equals.  You don't like to admit they exist - the other big people in your world are dead. I told you that.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: You talk about the people of the United States as though they belonged to you.  When you find out they don't think they are, you'll lose interest.  You talk about giving them their rights as though you could make a present of liberty.  Remember the working man?  You used to defend him quite a good deal.  Well, he's turning into something called organized labor and you don't like that at all.  And listen, when your precious underprivileged really get together - that's going to add up to something bigger than - than your privilege and then I don't know what you'll do - sail away to a desert island, probably, and lord it over the monkeys.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Are you finished?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Yes.  Now, will you let me go to Chicago?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You're not going to like it in Chicago.  They wind comes howling in from the lake.  And there's practically no opera season at all - and the Lord only knows whether they've ever heard of Lobster Newburg -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: That's all right.  What are you going to do about Emily?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Nothing - if she dosen't love me -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: You want love on your own terms, don't you, Charlie -  Love according to your own rules. And if anything goes wrong and you're hurt - then the game stops, and you've got to be soothed and nursed, no matter what else is happening - and no matter who else is hurt!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It's simpler than that, Brad.  A society girl can't stand the gaff, that's all.  Other things are important to her - social position, what they're saying on the front porches at Southampton, is it going to be embarrassing to meet somebody or the other at dinner -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: She can leave me.  As a matter of fact, I've already left her.  Don't worry, Brad - I'll live.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I know you will.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Hey, Brad!  I've been analyzed an awful lot tonight - let's have another brandy.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: To love on my terms.  Those are the only terms anybody knows ... his own.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Are you hurt?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: No.  I wish you'd go home to Emily. She'll be pretty upset by all this - She still loves you -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You still want to be transferred to the other paper?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I couldn't possibly live on as little as that, Charlie.  We'll let the salary stay where it is.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Excuse us a moment, please.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I said, excuse us a moment.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I've been talking to Leland.  Emily - You can't leave me now - not now -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It isn't what it would do to my changes in politics, Emily -  That isn't it -  They were talking of running me for governor, but now, of course, we'll have to wait - It isn't that, Emily -  It's just - the president is your uncle and they're saying I killed him.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: That story about the murderer having a copy of the "Enquirer" in his pocket - the "Chronicle" made that up out of whole cloth -  Emily, please - He's going to be all right, you know, he's going to recover -  If it will make you any happier, we had nine pages of advertising cancelled in the first mail this morning.  Bernstein is afraid to open any more letters.  He -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What do you expect me to do?  What in the world -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Charles.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Do you really think -  Those threatening letters, can they really -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Anonymous letter writers -   I've got guards in front of the house, and I'm going to arrange -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Please don't talk any more, Charles.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Have they heard from father yet? Has he seen -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I've tried to tell you, Emily. The President's going to be all right.  He had a comfortable night. There's no danger of any kind.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Here I am, darling...  Darling!... Darling, it's all right...  Mother's here.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Emily - you musn't leave me now - you can't do that to me.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: They won't hurt you, darling. Mother's with you!  Mother's looking after you!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: We'll withdraw support completely. Anything else?

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Mr. Leland sent back that check.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What check?

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: You made it out to him last week after he left for Chicago.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Oh, yes, the bonus.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: It was for twenty-five thousand dollars.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: He sent it back torn up - all torn up into little bits, and he enclosed something else -  I can't make it out.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: It says here, "A Declaration of Principles" -  "I will provide the people of this city with a daily paper that will tell all the news honestly" -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It is no secret that I entered upon this campaign with no thought that I could be elected Governor of this state!  It is now no secret that every straw vote, every independent pole, shows that I will be elected.  And I repeat to you - my first official act as Governor will be to appoint a special District Attorney to arrange for the indictment, prosecution and conviction of Boss Edward G. Rogers!

Speaker: second leader
Dialogue: One of the most notable public utterances ever made by a candidate in this state -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Thank you, gentlemen.  Thank you.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: A wonderful speech, Mr. Kane.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: I just got word from Buffalo, Mr. Kane.  They're going to throw you the organization vote - and take a chance maybe you'll give them a break -

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: On an independent ticket there's never been anything like it!  If the election were held today, you'd be elected by a hundred thousand votes - and every day between now and November 7th is just going to add to your majority.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It does seem too good to be true, doesn't it, Mr. Bernstein?

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Rogers isn't even pretending.  He isn't just scared anymore.  He's sick.  Frank Norris told me last night he hasn't known Rogers to be that worried in twenty-five years.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I think it's beginning to dawn on Mr. Rogers that I mean what I say. With Mr. Rogers out of the way, Reilly, I think we may really begin to hope for a good government in this state.  Well, Mr. Bernstein?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: It's wonderful, Mr. Kane. Wonderful.  Wonderful.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You don't really think so?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I do.  I do.  I mean, since you're running for Governor - and you want to be elected -  I think it's wonderful you're going to be elected.  Only -  -  Can I say something?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Please, Mr. Bernstein.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Well, the way I look at it -  -  You want to know what I really think would be wonderful?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Well, you're running for Governor and going to be elected - my idea is how wonderful it would be if you don't run at all and don't get elected.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Is Pop Governor yet, Mom?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Hello, Butch!  Did you like your old man's speech?

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Hello, Pop!  I was in a box.  I could hear every word.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I saw you!  Good night, gentlemen.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: I'm sending Junior home in the car, Charles - with Oliver -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: But I'd arranged to go home with you myself.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: There's a call I want you to make with me, Charles.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It can wait.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: No, it can't.  Good night, darling.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Good night, Mom.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What's this all about, Emily? I've had a very tiring day and -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: It may not be about anything at all.

Speaker: the driver
Dialogue: Cab?

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: I intend to find out.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I insist on being told exactly what you have in mind.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: I'm going to -  - 185 West 74th Street.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: If you wish, you can come with me...

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'll go with you.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I had no idea you had this flair for melodrama, Emiliy.

Speaker: the maid
Dialogue: Come in, Mr. Kane, come in.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: It wasn't my fault, Charlie.  He made me send your wife a note. He said I'd - oh, he's been saying the most terrible things, I didn't know what to do...  I -

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: Good evening, Mr. Kane.  I don't suppose anybody would introduce us.  Mrs. Kane, I am Edward Rogers.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: How do you do?  because I recieved this note -

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: I made Miss - Miss Alexander send you the note.  She was a little unwilling at first -  but she did it.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I can't tell you the things he said, Charlie.  You haven't got any idea -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: To start with, I'll break your neck.

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: Maybe you can do it and maybe you can't, Mr. Kane.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Charles!  for myself, and for my son.  What does this note mean, Miss -

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I know what you think, Mrs. Kane, but -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: What does this note mean, Miss Alexander?

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: She doesn't know, Mrs. Kane.  She just sent it - because I made her see it wouldn't be smart for her not to send it.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: In case you don't know, Emily, this - this gentleman -  is -

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: I'm not a gentleman, Mrs. Kane, and your husband is just trying to be funny calling me one.  I don't even know what a gentleman is.  It's pretty clear - I'm not a gentleman.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Oh!!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You're a cheap, crooked grafter - and your concern for your children and your mother -

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: Anything you say, Mr. Kane.  Only we're talking now about what you are.  That's what the note is about, Mrs. Kane.  Now I'm going to lay all my cards on the table.  I'm fighting for my life.  Not just my political life.  My life.  If your husband is elected governor -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'm going to be elected governor. And the first thing I'm going to do -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Let him finish, Charles.

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: I'm protecting myself every way I know how, Mrs. Kane.  This last week, I finally found out how I can stop your husband from being elected.  If the people of this state learn what I found out this week, he wouldn't have a chance to - he couldn't be elected Dog Catcher. Well, what I'm interested in is seeing that he's not elected.  I don't care whether they know what I know about him.  Let him keep right on being the Great, Noble, Moral -  Champeen of the people.  Just as long as -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: I think I understand, Mr. Rogers, but wonder if -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You can't blackmail me, Rogers, you can't -

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Charlie, he said, unless you withdrew your name -

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: That's the chance I'm willing to give you, Mr. Kane.  More of a chance than you'd give me.  Unless you make up your mind by tomorrow that you're so sick that you've got to go away for a year or two - Monday morning every paper in this State will carry the story I'm going to give them.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: What story, Mr. Rogers?

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: The story about him and Miss Alexander, Mrs. Kane.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: There is no story.  It's all lies. Mr. Kane is just -

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: I've had a dozen men doing nothing but run this thing down - we've got evidence enough to - well, the evidence would stand up in any court of law.  You want me to give you the evidence, Mr. Kane?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You do anything you want to do. The people of this state can decide which one of us to trust.  If you want to know, they've already decided.  The election Tuesday'll be only -

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: Mrs. Kane, I'm not asking you to believe me.  I'd like to show you -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: You don't have to show me anything, Mr. Rogers.  I believe you.

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: I'd rather Mr. Kane withdrew without having to get the story published. Not that I care about him.  But I'd be better off that way -  - and so would you, Mrs. Kane.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: What about me?  He said my name'd be dragged through the mud.  He said everywhere I'd go from now on -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: There seems to be only one decision you can make, Charles.  I'd say that it has been made for you.  I suppose the details can be arranged tomorrow, Mr. Rogers. About the statements by the doctors -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Have you gone completely mad, Emily?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: You don't think I'm going to let this blackmailer intimidate me, do you?

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: I don't see what else you can do, Charles.  If he's right - and the papers publish this story he has -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Oh, they'll publish it all right. But that's not going to stop me -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Charles, this - this story - doesn't concern only you.  I'll be in it, too, won't I?  And Junior?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I suppose so, but - I'm not afraid of the story.  You can't tell me that the voters of this state -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: I'm not interested in the voters of this state right now.  I am interested in - well, Junior, for one thing.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Charlie!  If they publish this story -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: They won't.  Goodnight, Mr. Rogers.  There's nothing more to be said, Charles.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Oh yes, there is.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: I don't think so.  Are you coming, Charles?

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: There's only one person in the world to decide what I'm going to do - and that's me.  And if you think - if any of you think -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: You decided what you were going to do, Charles - some time ago.  Come on, Charles.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Go on!  Get out!  I can fight this thing all alone!

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: You're making a bigger fool of yourself than I thought you would, Mr. Kane.  You're licked.  Why don't you -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Get out!  I've got nothing to talk to you about.  If you want to see me, have the Warden write me a letter.

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: I see!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Charlie, you're just excited.  You don't realize -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I know exactly what I'm doing.  Get out!

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Charles, if you don't listen to reason, it may be too late -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Too late for what?  Too late for you and this -  this public thief to take the love of the people of this state away from me?  Well, you won't do it, I tell you.  You won't do it!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Charlie, there are other things to think of.  Your son - you don't want him to read in the papers -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: It is too late now, Charles.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Get out, both of you!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Charlie, please don't -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What are you waiting here for? Why don't you go?

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Goodnight, Charles.

Speaker: rogers
Dialogue: You're the greatest fool I've ever known, Kane.  If it was anybody else, I'd say what's going to happen to you would be a lesson to you. Only you're going to need more than one lesson.  And you're going to get more than one lesson.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Don't you worry about me.  I'm Charles Foster Kane.  I'm no cheap, crooked politician, trying to save himself from the consequences of his crimes -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: I'm going to send you to Sing Sing, Rogers.  Sing Sing!

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Hello, Brad -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Emily -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: I'm sorry I sent for you, Brad - didn't -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Chicago is pretty close to New York nowadays - only twenty hours -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I'm glad to see you.

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Are all the returns in?

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Let me see it.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Almost two to one -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: I'm surprised he got the votes he did.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Emily!

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Why should anyone vote for him? He's made it quite clear to the people what he thinks of them. Children - to be told one thing one day, something else the next, as the whim seizes him.  And they're supposed to be grateful and love and adore him - because he sees to it that they get cheap ice and only pay a nickel in the street cars.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Emily, you're being - a little unfair -  You know what I think of Charles' behavior - about your personal lives -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: There aren't any personal lives for people like us.  He made that very clear to me nine years ago - If I'd thought of my life with Charles as a personal life, I'd have left him then -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: know that, Emily -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Maybe I should have - the first time he showed me what a mad dog he really was.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Emily, you -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Brad, I'm -  I'm not an old woman yet -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: It's - all over -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: Know it is, Brad -

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: He's paying for it, Emily.  Those returns tonight - he's finished. Politically -  - socially, everywhere, I guess. don't know about the papers, but -

Speaker: emily
Dialogue: If you're asking me to sympathize with him, Brad, you're wasting your time.  There's only one person I'm sorry for, as a matter of fact.  That - that shabby little girl.  I'm really sorry for her, Brad.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Leland.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Hello, Bernstein.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Where is it - where's my notice? I've got to finish it!

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Mr. Kane is finishing it.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Kane?  Charlie?  Where is he?

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I suppose he's fixing it up - I know I'd never get that through.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Mr. Kane is finishing your piece the way you started it.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: He's writing a roast like you wanted it to be -  - I guess that'll show you.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Hello, Brad.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Hello, Charlie -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Sure, we're speaking, Brad - you're fired.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Well, that's about all there is - and I'm getting chills.  Hey, nurse!  Sloppy Joe's?  What's the name of that place?  You know...  All right. Xanadu.  I knew what it was all the time.  You caught on, didn't you?

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I guess maybe I'm not as hard to see through as I think.  Anyway, I never even answered his letter. Maybe I should have.  I guess he was pretty lonely down there those last years.  He hadn't finished it when she left him - he never finished it - he never finished anything.  Of course, he built it for her -

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: That must have been love.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I don't know.  He was disappointed in the world.  So he built one of his own -  An absolute monarchy - It was something bigger than an opera house anyway -  Say, I'll tell you one thing you can do for me, young fellow.

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: On your way out, stop at a cigar store, will you, and send me up a couple of cigars?

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: Sure, Mr. Leland.  I'll be glad to.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: Hey, Nurse!

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Leland.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: I'm ready to go in now.  You know when I was a young man, there was an impression around that nurses were pretty.  It was no truer then than it is now.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Here, let me take your arm, Mr. Leland.

Speaker: leland
Dialogue: You won't forget, will you, about the cigars?  And tell them to wrap them up to look like toothpaste, or something, or they'll stop them at the desk.  That young doctor I was telling you about, he's got an idea he wants to keep me alive.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: How do you want to handle the whole thing - ask questions?

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: I'd rather you just talked. Anything that comes into your mind - about yourself and Mr. Kane.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: You wouldn't want to hear a lot of what comes into my mind about myself and Mr. Charlie Kane.

Speaker: thompson
Dialogue: How did you meet him?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I had a toothache.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: That was thiry years ago - and I still remember that toothache. Boy!  That toothache was just driving me crazy...

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Ow!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: It's not funny.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I'm sorry, mister - but you do look awful funny.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Ow!

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What's the matter with you?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Toothache.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: Hmm!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: You've got some on your face.

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: If these sidewalks were kept in condition - instead of the money going to some cheap grafter -

Speaker: kane
Dialogue: What's funny now?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: You are.  You look like you've been making mud pies.
